Laurie Strode.Action: Grouped shots strike with precision in the heart of a target, holding a smoking gun with years of anxiety evident but still showing capability.
Fires at mannequins, prepares weapons, isolated and defensive behaviors.
Maintains a fortified compound with tranquil wind chimes despite heavy security.
Disassembles and cleans firearms like a pro.
Practices shooting with a high power semi-automatic weapon at mannequins, demonstrating skill and preparation.
Examines a flat tire on her ATV, showing situational awareness and practical handling of problems.
Takes medication after practicing but continues with training, indicating knowledge of self-care and discipline.
Confidently states she doesn't feel isolated despite years of seclusion.
Dismisses attempts to re-examine traumatic past events, showing emotional closure or refusal to engage.
Responds skeptically but provocatively to Aaron's disbelief in the Boogeyman, showing control over the narrative.
Admits to being twice divorced and a basket case without defensiveness.
Responds with a sarcastic or slightly confrontational comment 'I didn't. But I bet you know that.'
Acknowledges Michael Myers as a human being despite his horrific actions.
Avoids sharing deeper insights or memories about the traumatic night.
Responds clearly and with assertiveness when questioned about Michael Myers and her past; maintains composure despite the uncomfortable topics.
Scavenges aimlessly after acknowledging she has no useful insight to provide.
Shows self-awareness and honesty about her flawed memories and personal struggles.
Engages in dialogue but does not volunteer additional information or take control of the conversation.
Approaches Shanah to discuss Allyson's involvement despite being warned not to communicate.
Acknowledges lack of control over who contacts her but stands firm on Allyson's autonomy.
Defends her parenting as protective and tries to appeal to Shanah's profession and empathy.
Sinks after Shanah dismisses her argument, showing emotional discouragement.
Attempts to connect by explaining her efforts to have Michael Myers transferred, showing responsibility and awareness of her past.
Uses the yo-yo to distract herself from her issues, indicating avoidance rather than addressing problems directly.
Initiates conversation with Cameron, greeting and interacting confidently despite being buzzed and twitchy.
Observes and comments on Cameron's handshake with a sense of discernment.
Acknowledges her own shortcomings as a mom with self-awareness.
Behavior appears slightly unsteady (buzzed, twitchy, sniffling) suggesting a lack of full control or composure.
Attempts humor and loudly demands drinks, possibly disrupting the situation.
Jokes teasingly with Cameron about his family and granddaughter, but immediately says 'Jesus, I'm just kidding' after being reprimanded.
Accidentally causes glasses and plates to shatter loudly in a restaurant, drawing unwanted attention and embarrassment to Allyson.
Walks toward a busy street and stops just before getting hit by cars; then shares an embrace with Allyson.
Teases Cameron to lighten the mood, demonstrating social confidence and quick wit.
Accidentally walks into a waiter carrying a tray, causing glasses and plates to shatter loudly in a public place.
Remains composed and walks out of the embarrassing situation, showing a degree of emotional control and confidence.
Nearly walks into oncoming traffic, requiring Allyson to intervene and prevent an accident.
Lives every day preparing for the past trauma, trained to shoot and fight extensively.
Chooses to forget the neurosis planted by her mother, indicating some mental strength and self-awareness.
Relies on intense preparation driven by fear rather than calm strategy, showing a possible limitation in emotional regulation.
Locates and opens a hidden storm shelter, climbs down a ladder, and enters the shelter confidently.
Uses a paper towel to avoid touching dirty stall doors, chooses a cleaner stall.
Defaces graffiti in a humorous way to lighten the mood, showing presence of mind.
Flinches and reacts with fear when stall doors are slammed open nearby.
Politely asks 'Excuse me. Someone's in here...' when confronted with the intruder.
Appears holding a pistol at the top of the stairs to protect Shanah and warns about home security risks.
Appears at the top of the stairs holding a pistol, ready to defend the house.
Analyzes the security risks of the house, pointing out an unlocked window and lack of security system.
Criticizes the lack of preparedness humorously but pointedly.
Acknowledges the ongoing threat posed by Michael and prepares mentally to protect her family.
Asks if anyone has a gun and shows concern about safety.
Wants to train and protect her daughter against real danger.
Confronts Ray and Shanah despite their dismissiveness, but is ignored.
Is emotionally affected by Shanah's rejection and the feeling of being powerless.
Listens to the police scanner attentively and immediately responds to a call about an intrusion by taking off determinedly towards the location.
Uneasily scans the neighborhood, showing alertness and concern for safety.
Raises her gun and fires at the perceived threat, directly confronting danger.
Uneasily scans the neighborhood and surveys the street and shadows upon arrival, showing cautious awareness.
Raises her gun and fires directly at the target upon seeing The Shape, showing quick reaction and confidence.
Mistakes the reflection of The Shape in a mirror for the real target and fires at it.
Tells Officer Hawkins to finish the attacker if he finds him before she does.
Shows readiness and responsibility by carrying and revealing her licensed firearm openly.
Confidently reveals she is licensed to carry a firearm and shows a Glock 34 to Officer Hawkins.
Prays that the antagonist would escape so she could kill him, showing a proactive and determined mindset.
Refuses to go with the authorities, stating she needs to protect her family, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Speaks tenderly on the phone to Allyson, urging her to seek help and reassuring her with 'We love you'
Speaks calmly and reassuringly to Allyson over the phone during a crisis, instructing her to find police for safety.
Expresses clear concern and organizes communication among others worried about Allyson's safety.
Types in a password to open a security gate, demonstrating familiarity and control of her home security system.
Looks at her reflection in the window while others handle the phone call, possibly indicating self-awareness and calm under pressure.
Types in a password to access a secure gun cabinet, shows knowledge of various weapons and their uses.
Has prepared an underground shelter with food, water, weapons, and a bed to protect herself.
Exhibits confidence while discussing weapons and readiness despite emotional undercurrents.
Grabs Shanah's weapon and looks her in the eye, explains the need to fight to survive, shows understanding of Shanah's fear.
Apologizes to Shanah for everything, expressing remorse and emotional vulnerability.
Hugs Shanah tightly after seeing her daughter's fear and tears, reconnecting emotionally.
Walks down stairs holding a pump action 12-gauge shotgun, looks for Ray, sees the Shape over Ray's body, locks the door to protect herself and Shanah.
Shushes Shanah and warns her 'He's here Shanah...'
Carries a pump action 12-gauge shotgun while moving cautiously through the house, locks the door upon seeing the killer, signals Shanah to be quiet and warns her about the danger calmly.
Commands others to seek safety, takes responsibility for others, and confronts the threat head-on.
Uses her shotgun skillfully in close combat to disable opponent’s hand and force retreat.
Maintains composure under attack, reacts quickly and decisively in life-threatening situation.
Tells Allyson to run and save herself despite personal danger; expresses love sincerely.
Acts protectively, confronting The Shape with determination to shield Allyson.
Maintains a calm, controlled expression even while injured, reassuring Shanah silently.
In moments of extreme danger and injury, remains conscious enough to urge others to kill The Shape and survive, showing presence of mind and trust in her companions.
Relies on Shanah and Allyson’s help and allows herself to be cared for and supported by them, demonstrating trust and allowing closeness.
Shows no hesitation or selfishness in letting others risk themselves and take initiative for her survival, indicating a sincere bond and cooperative warmth.
Looks back at The Shape disappearing into the trees despite being nearly unconscious.
Whispers 'Kill it. Kill it. It must die.' showing clear intent and determination despite pain and exhaustion.
Relies on others for support and transport due to severe injury and near unconsciousness.
Responds to uninvited guests with cold suspicion and gives no welcoming reply.
Maintains heavy security and is armed inside her home.
Cleans her revolver carefully, checking the bullet, engaging the cylinder, and cocking the hammer, showing familiarity and preparedness with the weapon.
Monitors four security camera monitors and notices uninvited guests arriving, demonstrating alertness and situational awareness.
Does not respond directly to visitors despite their repeated attempts and offers to pay, indicating guardedness or reluctance to engage without verifying their intent.
Responds to the question about feeling isolated by saying 'I don't.' without elaboration.
Dismisses opportunity to learn from past trauma, stating 'There's nothing to re-examine. Nothing to learn from something that happened forty years ago.'
Engages briefly and somewhat cryptically with Aaron regarding belief in the Boogeyman, implying others should believe in it.
Engages in a difficult conversation with her daughter Shanah, expressing concern and hoping for empathy regarding her parenting choices.
Insists on Allyson joining Shanah's group despite being told not to have communication, showing persistence but also possibly disregarding boundaries.
Attempting to connect by sharing her struggle and desire to put the past behind her with Shanah
Turns to leave after Shanah speaks, initially not engaging further
Ambiguously deflects personal issues by focusing on untangling a yo-yo
Walks up to the group, greets Allyson and others with a wink, introduces herself to Cameron warmly with a handshake.
Makes a light joke about Ray's handshake not being clammy, showing friendliness and humor.
Notices Allyson's honor award and picks it up, showing interest in Allyson's achievements.
Admits self-criticism about being a bad mom whether she shows up or not, displaying sincerity and vulnerability.
Loudly calls out for a waiter, somewhat disrupting the mood and possibly embarrassing others.
Wakes up tired after a tough night, makes coffee while attending to news, prepares defensively by arming herself and securing her house
Expresses deep concern for her family's safety and wants to protect them from Michael.
Thinks that Shanah is always trying to leave her behind and seems hurt by it.
Desires to train and protect Shanah out of love and fear for her safety.
Shanah shutting the door in Laurie's face after Laurie asks about a gun; Laurie pauses and looks at both of them.
Tells Ray to shut up dismissively.
Driving down the street while listening to the police scanner, remaining alert and anxious, carefully observing surroundings.
Punches Officer Hawkins sharply when startled, swears at him, and says 'Don't creep on a girl in the dark unless you want to get punched.'
Shoots The Shape to protect herself and others, acts decisively in a dangerous situation.
Laurie spots The Shape, raises her gun, fires accurately hitting him in the shoulder, and pursues cautiously around the corner.
Laurie punches Officer Hawkins in the face impulsively when startled instead of communicating calmly.
Laurie verbally asserts her frustration but fails to provide useful information about The Shape's whereabouts after losing him.
Approaches the sheriff and officer to offer help during a dangerous situation.
Makes a light, friendly comment about Dr. Sartain's accent to establish rapport.
Interrupts an urgent police conversation to introduce herself and engage with authorities.
Attempts to assert her presence despite being told her help is not needed.
Makes a confident and insightful comment regarding Dr. Sartain being the new Loomis based on his accent.
Prays every day that he would escape, so she could kill him.
Refuses to go with Dr. Sartain because she needs to protect her family.
Reassures and holds her daughter's hand, expresses that she never wanted her scared but prepared.
Shares information about the shelter as a means of protection and survival.
Shows no invitation or offer to share resources or comfort with others besides general preparedness.
Grabs Shanah's weapon and firmly looks her in the eye, asserting the need to fight to survive and showing preparedness for the confrontation.
Acknowledges Shanah's fear and unpreparedness, responds with empathy and a sincere apology, demonstrating emotional intelligence and awareness.
Has been preparing for a long time for the threat, shows strategic foresight and readiness for the danger.
Instructs Shanah to go to the shelter to keep her safe and takes responsibility to handle the threat herself.
Focuses on protecting others and facing danger directly rather than fleeing or avoiding responsibility.
Comforts her mother by calling her 'Sweetheart' while correcting her about the gun.
Maintains high alert and fires at suspected intruder repeatedly to protect herself and others.
Observes Allyson crying over her dead father but does not immediately comfort her or intervene.
